For each number, check if target - num exists in the map

questions.title: Valid Perfect Square
questions.introduction: Given a positive integer num, return true if num is a perfect square or false otherwise. A perfect square is an integer that is the square of an integer. You must not use any built-in library function, such as sqrt.
questions.problemStatement:
Determine if num is a perfect square without using sqrt.

Constraints:
- 1 <= num <= 2^31 - 1

examples.explanation: 4 * 4 = 16, so 16 is a perfect square.
No integer squared equals 14.

hints: Binary search for the square root
Check if mid * mid equals num exactly
Handle integer overflow carefully

questions.title: Find Smallest Letter Greater Than Target
questions.introduction: You are given an array of characters letters that is sorted in non-decreasing order, and a character target. There are at least two different characters in letters. Return the smallest character in letters that is lexicographically greater than target. If such a character does not exist, return the first character in letters.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the smallest letter greater than target (wraps around).

Constraints:
- 2 <= letters.length <= 10^4
- letters[i] is a lowercase English letter
- letters is sorted in non-decreasing order
- letters contains at least two different characters
- target is a lowercase English letter

examples.explanation: The smallest character greater than 'a' is 'c'.
The smallest character strictly greater than 'c' is 'f'.
No character greater than 'z', so wrap to 'x'.

hints: Binary search for the first letter greater than target
If not found, return the first letter (wrap around)
Use left pointer at the end as the answer

questions.title: Time Based Key-Value Store
questions.introduction: Design a time-based key-value data structure that can store multiple values for the same key at different time stamps and retrieve the key's value at a certain timestamp. The timestamps are strictly increasing for the same key.
questions.problemStatement:
Implement TimeMap with set(key, value, timestamp) and get(key, timestamp).

Constraints:
- 1 <= key.length, value.length <= 100
- key and value consist of lowercase English letters and digits
- 1 <= timestamp <= 10^7
- All timestamps of set are strictly increasing
- At most 2 * 10^5 calls to set and get

examples.explanation: get("foo", 1) returns "bar". get("foo", 3) returns "bar" (latest before 3). get("foo", 4) returns "bar2". get("foo", 5) returns "bar2".

hints: Store values with timestamps in a list for each key
Use binary search to find the largest timestamp <= given timestamp
HashMap with key -> list of (timestamp, value) pairs
questions.timeComplexity: O(log n) for get, O(1) for set

questions.title: Find K Closest Elements
questions.introduction: Given a sorted integer array arr, two integers k and x, return the k closest integers to x in the array. The result should also be sorted in ascending order. An integer a is closer to x than an integer b if |a - x| < |b - x|, or |a - x| == |b - x| and a < b.
questions.problemStatement:
Find k elements closest to x in a sorted array.

Constraints:
- 1 <= k <= arr.length
- 1 <= arr.length <= 10^4
- arr is sorted in ascending order
- -10^4 <= arr[i], x <= 10^4

examples.explanation: 4 closest elements to 3 are [1,2,3,4].
4 closest elements to -1 are [1,2,3,4].

hints: Binary search for the left boundary of the k-element window
Compare arr[mid] and arr[mid+k] distances to x
Window starting position is the answer

questions.title: Single Element in a Sorted Array
questions.introduction: You are given a sorted array consisting of only integers where every element appears exactly twice, except for one element which appears exactly once. Return the single element that appears only once.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the single non-duplicate element in O(log n) time.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- 0 <= nums[i] <= 10^5

examples.explanation: 2 is the single element that appears only once.
10 is the single element that appears only once.

hints: Before the single element, pairs are at (even, odd) indices
After the single element, pairs are at (odd, even) indices
Use this property to binary search

questions.title: Search in Rotated Sorted Array II
questions.introduction: There is an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order (not necessarily with distinct values). Before being passed to your function, nums is rotated at an unknown pivot index. Given the array nums after the rotation and an integer target, return true if target is in nums, or false if it is not in nums.
questions.problemStatement:
Search in a rotated sorted array that may contain duplicates.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 5000
- -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4
- nums is guaranteed to be rotated at some pivot
- -10^4 <= target <= 10^4

examples.explanation: 0 exists in the array.
3 does not exist in the array.

hints: Similar to Search in Rotated Sorted Array I
When nums[left] == nums[mid] == nums[right], skip duplicates
Worst case is O(n) due to duplicates

questions.title: Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array II
questions.introduction: Suppose an array of length n sorted in ascending order is rotated between 1 and n times. Given the sorted rotated array nums that may contain duplicates, return the minimum element of this array.
questions.problemStatement:
Find minimum in a rotated sorted array with duplicates.

Constraints:
- n == nums.length
- 1 <= n <= 5000
- -5000 <= nums[i] <= 5000
- nums is sorted and rotated between 1 and n times

examples.explanation: The original array was [1,3,5] and it was rotated 3 times (no change).
The minimum is 0.

hints: Similar to Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array I
When nums[mid] == nums[right], decrement right
This handles the ambiguity caused by duplicates

questions.title: Pow(x, n)
questions.introduction: Implement pow(x, n), which calculates x raised to the power n.
questions.problemStatement:
Calculate x^n efficiently.

Constraints:
- -100.0 < x < 100.0
- -2^31 <= n <= 2^31 - 1
- n is an integer
- Either x is not zero or n > 0
- -10^4 <= x^n <= 10^4
hints: Use binary exponentiation (fast power)
x^n = (x^(n/2))^2 if n is even
Handle negative exponents by inverting x

questions.title: Find the Duplicate Number
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers nums containing n + 1 integers where each integer is in the range [1, n] inclusive. There is only one repeated number in nums, return this repeated number. You must solve the problem without modifying the array nums and uses only constant extra space.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the duplicate number in O(1) space without modifying the array.

Constraints:
- 1 <= n <= 10^5
- nums.length == n + 1
- 1 <= nums[i] <= n
- All integers in nums appear only once except for precisely one integer which appears two or more times

examples.explanation: 2 is the duplicate number.
3 is the duplicate number.
3 is the duplicate number.

hints: Binary search on the value range [1, n]
Count numbers <= mid; if count > mid, duplicate is in [1, mid]
Alternative: Floyd's cycle detection (tortoise and hare)

questions.title: H-Index II
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers citations where citations[i] is the number of citations a researcher received for their ith paper and citations is sorted in ascending order, return the researcher's h-index.
questions.problemStatement:
Find h-index in a sorted citations array in O(log n) time.

Constraints:
- n == citations.length
- 1 <= n <= 10^5
- 0 <= citations[i] <= 1000
- citations is sorted in ascending order

examples.explanation: The researcher has 3 papers with at least 3 citations each.
The researcher has 2 papers with at least 2 citations each.

hints: Binary search for the h-index
At index i, there are (n - i) papers with >= citations[i] citations
Find smallest i where citations[i] >= n - i

questions.title: Magnetic Force Between Two Balls
questions.introduction: In the universe Earth C-137, Rick discovered a special form of magnetic force between two balls if they are put in his new invented basket. Rick has n empty baskets, the ith basket is at position[i]. Morty has m balls and needs to distribute the balls into the baskets such that the minimum magnetic force between any two balls is maximum.
questions.problemStatement:
Maximize the minimum distance between any two balls placed in baskets.

Constraints:
- n == position.length
- 2 <= n <= 10^5
- 1 <= position[i] <= 10^9
- All integers in position are distinct
- 2 <= m <= position.length

examples.explanation: Place balls at positions 1, 4, 7. Minimum distance is 3.
Place balls at positions 1 and 1000000000.

hints: Binary search on the answer (minimum distance)
For each distance, greedily check if m balls can be placed
Range is from 1 to (max - min) / (m - 1)
questions.timeComplexity: O(n log n + n log(max - min))

questions.title: Minimize Max Distance to Gas Station
questions.introduction: You are given an integer array stations that represents the positions of the gas stations on the x-axis. You are also given an integer k. You should add k new gas stations. Find the minimum value of the maximum distance d between adjacent gas stations after adding the k new stations.
questions.problemStatement:
Minimize the maximum gap between gas stations after adding k stations.

Constraints:
- 10 <= stations.length <= 2000
- 0 <= stations[i] <= 10^8
- stations is sorted in strictly increasing order
- 1 <= k <= 10^6

examples.explanation: After adding 9 stations optimally, max gap is 0.5.
Adding 1 station between 84 and 98 gives max gap 14.

hints: Binary search on the answer (maximum distance)
For each distance d, calculate stations needed to achieve it
Use floating-point binary search with precision
questions.timeComplexity: O(n log(W/eps)) where W is max gap

questions.title: Random Pick with Weight
questions.introduction: You are given a 0-indexed array of positive integers w where w[i] describes the weight of the ith index. Implement the function pickIndex() which randomly picks an index in the range [0, w.length - 1] and returns it. The probability of picking an index i is w[i] / sum(w).
questions.problemStatement:
Implement weighted random selection.

Constraints:
- 1 <= w.length <= 10^4
- 1 <= w[i] <= 10^5
- pickIndex will be called at most 10^4 times

examples.explanation: Only index 0 exists, so pickIndex returns 0.
Index 1 has 75% probability, index 0 has 25%.

hints: Build a prefix sum array of weights
Generate random number in range [1, total_weight]
Binary search for the index in prefix sum array

questions.title: Count of Smaller Numbers After Self
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums, return an integer array counts where counts[i] is the number of smaller elements to the right of nums[i].
questions.problemStatement:
For each element, count how many elements to its right are smaller.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4

examples.explanation: To the right of 5 there are 2 smaller (2 and 1). To the right of 2 there is 1 smaller (1). To the right of 6 there is 1 smaller (1). To the right of 1 there are 0 smaller.
No elements to the right.
No smaller elements to the right of either element.

hints: Process from right to left, maintaining a sorted list
Use binary search to find insertion position
Insertion position = count of smaller elements

questions.title: Kth Smallest Element in a Sorted Matrix
questions.introduction: Given an n x n matrix where each of the rows and columns is sorted in ascending order, return the kth smallest element in the matrix. Note that it is the kth smallest element in the sorted order, not the kth distinct element.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the kth smallest element in a row and column sorted matrix.

Constraints:
- n == matrix.length == matrix[i].length
- 1 <= n <= 300
- -10^9 <= matrix[i][j] <= 10^9
- All rows and columns are sorted in non-decreasing order
- 1 <= k <= n^2

examples.explanation: The elements in order are [1,5,9,10,11,12,13,13,15], and the 8th is 13.
Only one element.

hints: Binary search on the value range [min, max]
For each value, count elements <= it in O(n) time
Find smallest value with count >= k

questions.title: Aggressive Cows / Allocate Books
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers A of size N and an integer B, find the maximum value of the minimum distance between B cows placed in the stalls. Alternatively: Given N books with pages[i] and M students, allocate books such that the maximum pages assigned to a student is minimized.
questions.problemStatement:
Classic binary search on answer problem for resource allocation.

Constraints:
- 2 <= N <= 10^5
- 2 <= B <= N
- 0 <= A[i] <= 10^9

examples.explanation: Place cows at positions 1, 4, 8. Minimum distance is 3.
Allocate [12, 34, 67] and [90]. Max is 113.

hints: Binary search on the answer
For cows: search for maximum minimum distance
For books: search for minimum maximum pages

questions.title: Peak Index in a Mountain Array
questions.introduction: An array arr is a mountain if arr.length >= 3 and there exists some i with 0 < i < arr.length - 1 such that arr[0] < arr[1] < ... < arr[i - 1] < arr[i] and arr[i] > arr[i + 1] > ... > arr[arr.length - 1]. Given a mountain array arr, return the index i such that arr[0] < arr[1] < ... < arr[i - 1] < arr[i] > arr[i + 1] > ... > arr[arr.length - 1].
questions.problemStatement:
Find the peak index in a mountain array in O(log n) time.

Constraints:
- 3 <= arr.length <= 10^5
- 0 <= arr[i] <= 10^6
- arr is guaranteed to be a mountain array

examples.explanation: Peak is at index 1.
Peak is at index 1.
Peak is at index 1.

hints: Binary search for the peak
If arr[mid] < arr[mid + 1], peak is on the right
Otherwise, peak is on the left (including mid)
